citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A kitten, id #M232577, was noted missing ½ of his tail on 26March23. According to the medical record, the facility staff
failed to handle the injury as described in the SOP or contact the veterinarian. When employees are not following
methods for treatment as outlined by the SOPs approved by the AV, the methods used may not be appropriate and go
against AV guidance. This issue needs to be addressed to assure that employees are treating animals as instructed by
the AV. Correct by: May 30, 2023

The same kitten, #M232577, had an observational note in the medical records on 31March2023 that the tail would take 4-
6 weeks to heal. At the time of the notation, the cat was housed with his litter mates and dam. On 05April2023 there was
a notation that the tail had healed, the cat was doing well, and the cat was moved to a grow out enclosure. His new
enclosure housed male kittens of the same age. The kitten was euthanized that same day and the disposition record
stated that the tail was injured and was healing but had been chewed to the bone by the other kittens in the enclosure.
The medical notes have the potential to cause confusion as one note stated the tail would take 4-6 weeks to heal, but the
next entry stated that the tail was all healed 6 days later. Placing this kitten in a new enclosure with a new group of males
and insufficient behavioral observations, when there was still an apparent injury, did not ensure his safety and the facility’s
ability to quickly intervene when the other kittens began to chew on the injured tail. All cats and kittens housed in the
same primary enclosure must be compatible, as determined by observation for the safety and health of the animals.
Correct by: May 20, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
KERI LUPO, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A kitten, id #M232577, was noted missing ½ of his tail on 26March23. According to the medical record, the facility staff 
failed to handle the injury as described in the SOP or contact the veterinarian. When employees are not following 
methods for treatment as outlined by the SOPs approved by the AV, the methods used may not be appropriate and go 
against AV guidance. This issue needs to be addressed to assure that employees are treating animals as instructed by 
the AV. Correct by: May 30, 2023 
3.6(b)(2)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
The same kitten, #M232577, had an observational note in the medical records on 31March2023 that the tail would take 4-
6 weeks to heal. At the time of the notation, the cat was housed with his litter mates and dam. On 05April2023 there was 
a notation that the tail had healed, the cat was doing well, and the cat was moved to a grow out enclosure. His new 
enclosure housed male kittens of the same age. The kitten was euthanized that same day and the disposition record 
stated that the tail was injured and was healing but had been chewed to the bone by the other kittens in the enclosure. 
The medical notes have the potential to cause confusion as one note stated the tail would take 4-6 weeks to heal, but the 
next entry stated that the tail was all healed 6 days later. Placing this kitten in a new enclosure with a new group of males 
and insufficient behavioral observations, when there was still an apparent injury, did not ensure his safety and the facility’s 
ability to quickly intervene when the other kittens began to chew on the injured tail. All cats and kittens housed in the 
same primary enclosure must be compatible, as determined by observation for the safety and health of the animals.  
Correct by: May 20, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KERI LUPO, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
